render.tex: \title{Cartesian and Vector forms of a line} \\ %text Cartesian and Vector forms of a line in three dimensionsional space and their relationship %

reason.tex: %text The cartesian form for the equation of a line passing through the points $x_1$, $y_1$, $z_1$ and having direction ratios $a$, $b$ and $c$ is, % \begin{align} \dfrac{x-x_1}{a}=\dfrac{y-y_1}{b}=\dfrac{z-z_1}{c} \end{align} \\ %text Therefore the coordinates of any point on this line are, % \begin{align} (a\lambda+x_1), (b\lambda+y_1), (c\lambda+z_1), \text{ where} \lambda\in\mathbb{R} \end{align} \\ %text In vector notation, the position vector $\ora{r}$ of any point on this line can be expressed as, % \begin{align} \ora{r}&=\vector{(x_1+a\lambda)}{(y_1+b\lambda)}{(z_1+c\lambda)} \\ &=\vector{x_1}{y_1}{z_1}+\lambda(\vector{a}{b}{c}) \\ &=\ora{p}+\lambda\ora{q} \end{align} \\ %text where $\ora{p}$ is a known point on the line and $\ora{q}$ is a vector representing the direction (ratios) of the line. %
